coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions have continued to rise with the sustained reliance on fossil fuels. One leading solution to capturing CO2 emissions is ultrathin film composite (UTFC) membranes due to their cost-efficiency and relatively low environmental impact. On-going efforts to overcome the challenges of practical membrane technology have included increased gas selectivity and robustness toward the low partial pressure of CO2 emitted from coal-fired power stations. Poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDXL) has been discovered to have exceptional CO2/N2 selectivity outperforming similar high-polar polymers including poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), PolyActive™, and Pebax®. However, designing as a composite membrane with PDXL has never been accomplished due to a vital challenge of poor interlayer adhesion, and this has restricted its further advancements. The surface-confined Continuous Assembly of Polymers (CAP) technology can be used to overcome the issue of poor interlayer adhesion; however this strategy needs to be modified to ensure all layers are covalently linked. In this study, we synthesized crosslinkable poly(1,3-dioxolane) dimethacrylate (PDXLDMA) and fabricated UTFC membranes via a revised CAP process. The resulting PDXL-based UTFC membrane demonstrated the highest CO2/N2 selectivity (71.3) ever achieved under dry conditions, while maintaining a gas permeance of above 1000 GPU. The modified CAP process preserved PDXL's inherent properties in the UTFC membrane and demonstrated excellent chemical and mechanical strength through crosslinked layers and covalent bonding of the multilayer structure.

head.ce:title: Breaking barriers: Unleashing CO2 selectivity with ultrathin poly(1,3-dioxolane) composite membranes produced by continuous assembly of polymers

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions have continued to rise with the sustained reliance on fossil fuels. One leading solution to capturing CO2 emissions is ultrathin film composite (UTFC) membranes due to their cost-efficiency and relatively low environmental impact. On-going efforts to overcome the challenges of practical membrane technology have included increased gas selectivity and robustness toward the low partial pressure of CO2 emitted from coal-fired power stations. Poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDXL) has been discovered to have exceptional CO2/N2 selectivity outperforming similar high-polar polymers including poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), PolyActive™, and Pebax®. However, designing as a composite membrane with PDXL has never been accomplished due to a vital challenge of poor interlayer adhesion, and this has restricted its further advancements. The surface-confined Continuous Assembly of Polymers (CAP) technology can be used to overcome the issue of poor interlayer adhesion; however this strategy needs to be modified to ensure all layers are covalently linked. In this study, we synthesized crosslinkable poly(1,3-dioxolane) dimethacrylate (PDXLDMA) and fabricated UTFC membranes via a revised CAP process. The resulting PDXL-based UTFC membrane demonstrated the highest CO2/N2 selectivity (71.3) ever achieved under dry conditions, while maintaining a gas permeance of above 1000 GPU. The modified CAP process preserved PDXL's inherent properties in the UTFC membrane and demonstrated excellent chemical and mechanical strength through crosslinked layers and covalent bonding of the multilayer structure.

PDXL-UTFC membranes were successfully fabricated with a newly synthesized macrocrosslinker, PDXLDMA, and modified CAPATRP technique for the first time.
Image 1

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Increasing demand to reduce atmospheric CO2 gas is an urgent task worldwide as it contributes to severe environmental damage including global warming. Membrane separation technologies are promising candidates to separate CO2 gas from other gases over other methods such as absorption, adsorption, and cryogenic process due to their great processability and cost-effectiveness [1]. Thin-film composite (TFC) membranes are preferred in industrial applications over dense membranes including mixed-matrix membranes (<∼50 μm) because the gas permeance can be increased by producing a thinner layer which has lower manufacturing costs due to smaller amount of materials required [2]. However, a decrease in membrane thickness typically form pinholes, which leads to a reduction in selectivity. To overcome this, many strategies have been studied including crosslinked polymer films, surface modification, interfacial polymerization, and additives [3]. Although those approaches showed improved gas separation performance, their poor controllability limits their practical applications.

A typical TFC membrane consists of a highly porous supporting layer giving ultrahigh permeable properties with great mechanical strength, a gutter layer (intermediate layer) that offers a smooth and comparable surface for a subsequent layer, and a top selective layer that selectively permeates CO2 gas over other gases [4]. In order to produce a successful multilayer-structured membrane, a gutter layer is first applied onto the porous substrate prior to the coating of other selective layers. This gutter layer plays a crucial role in maintaining a thin top layer and preventing material penetration into the substrate's pores which would result in a reduction of gas permeance. Among the materials used for the gutter layer, polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is most used due to its high gas permeability (∼3,800 Barrer) and good processability [5,6]. However, their low surface energy reduces compatibility between the PDMS gutter layer and selective layer which have different hydrophilicities, thus both have to be modified in order to improve the adhesion between the layers [7]. Consequently, the poor adhesive interface limits the range of the polymer selection for the top selective layer.

For a selective layer with extreme high gas selectivity, materials with strong CO2 interactions are essential. Facilitated transport membranes are one class of membranes which permeate CO2 via two main mechanisms, physical diffusion and reversible chemical reaction [8]. One example utilizes polyvinylamine (PVAm) and presented enhanced CO2 permeability and CO2/N2 selectivity with increasing relative humidity (RH) [9,10]. However, their CO2 permeation mechanism requires humid feed gasses, and the presence of water in many industrial applications may not be possible or can vary, significantly impact the separation performance. In some cases, hydrolysis may result in irreversible reactions [11]. The other class of membranes aims at utilizing selective materials for TFC membranes, based on a gas solution-diffusion mechanism and can perform under dry conditions, which is more amenable to many industrial applications [12]. However, finding materials with exceptionally high selectivity and a suitable permeability has always been challenging. Among them, poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and its derivatives are commonly employed for selective layers due to their great solubility from the high ether oxygen contents [4]. Increasing ether groups in the material structure can enhance the CO2 over other gases selectivity because of the greater oxygen affinity of CO2 compared to other gases. However, high crystallinity (71 vol%) of pristine PEO, hinders further application [4,13]. Liu et al. have recently reported that poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDXL) based membranes show higher CO2 solubility than other gases and surpasses the CO2/gases selectivity of PEO-based copolymers. These dense membranes were successfully fabricated with high gas separation performance (CO2/N2 selectivity of ∼70 with 200 Barrer at 35 °C) via UV free-radical polymerization [14]. Although PDXL possesses great potential, its use as the selective layer for a TFC membrane poses a significant challenge as it is a hydrophilic material which is incompatible with hydrophobic gutter layer surface. Such incompatibility causes weak adhesive behavior between the two layers, often leading to fissures [15,16]. O2 plasma treatment has been used to improve adhesion, but this may generate pinholes during exposure, which can lead to membrane leakage [17,18]. To overcome differences in their hydrophilicity, we present a polymer grafting technique as a solution for this challenge.

For high-performing thin-film membrane fabrication, a crosslinked layer is preferred because this design can increase the ether groups in the structure with amorphous phases, which results in higher gas separation performance without crystallization [19]. In addition, from a commercialization point of view, this approach can offer high chemical stability and thermal resistance. However, few crosslinked polymers, such as polyimide and polyacrylonitrile/polydimethylsiloxane, have been commercialized because the major challenge in membrane manufacturing is the solubility of these materials. Strong acids are generally required to dissolve materials that hinder efficient membrane production [20].

The continuous assembly of polymers (CAP) technology is one of the most capable approaches for producing a successful multilayered composite membrane with a strongly crosslinked and strong adhesion between layers. It provides controllable crosslinking chemistry of grafting-from and grafting-to methods, resulting in a covalently bonded and crosslinked ultrathin layer from the various tailor-made polymer [21]. There are various controlled polymerization methods that can be utilized such as ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP, CAPROMP) [22,23], photoinduced CAP (CAPphoto) [24], atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP, CAPATRP) [21,25,26], and reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT, CAPRAFT) [27]. Structural heterogeneity is dominated by conventional free radical polymerizations due to their rapid chain growth and insufficient segmental relaxation time, therefore it is important to carry out precise crosslinking reactions to ensure desirable mechanical properties [28]. Furthermore, conventional free radical polymerization cannot form surface confined crosslinked films, which the controlled polymerization methods can offer. In particular, CAPATRP can offer a uniform and denser thin polymer selective layer on non-flat surfaces compared to other approaches [21]. In order to achieve a successful CAPATRP reaction, ATRP can be initiated using a variety of strategies, such as modifying the porous substrate and introducing an initiation layer either directly applying it onto a porous substrate or on the top of the gutter layer. The top layer produced using the CAP process can achieve an ultrathin and durable selective layer. Our recent work on precision fabrication of the gutter layer has allowed us to produce the middle layer with a permeance above 14,000 GPU [6]. With these recent advances, UTFC membranes can now achieve a gas permeance between 1,000 and 3,500 GPU. However, the selectivity of these membranes still remains relatively low. Since there is a trade-off between permeance and selectivity of CO2 against other gases, it remains challenging to achieve a selectivity of more than 60 while maintaining gas permeance above 1,000 GPU in existing TFC membranes.

It is important to employ a separated initiation layer to create a uniform and smoother surface for a successful ATRP reaction. However, when a hydrophilic top layer is used, using our previous CAP method, the initiation layer could potentially result in poor repeatability in membrane fabrication and cause delamination during the CAP process due to insufficient crosslinking degree. Therefore, a modified CAP process is required to address this issue and overcome the barrier of incompatibility between hydrophilic top layer and hydrophobic gutter layer. We hypothesize that if we can find a top layer material with the highest selectivity and apply a modified CAP method with precision gutter layer formation technology, it is possible to build a TFC membrane with a performance surpassing the upper limit of selectivity of 60, while maintaining a CO2 permeance of more than 1000 GPU. Given the properties of PDXL, this hypothesis becomes feasible.

In this study, we successfully fabricate PDXL ultrathin composite (UTFC) membranes for the first time with a newly synthesized macrocrosslinker, poly(1,3-dioxolane) dimethacrylate (PDXLDMA) to form the top layer precursor. We modified the CAPATRP method by introducing a crosslinked PDMS-based initiation layer; so, avoiding any potential delamination. The resulting UTFC membrane exhibits exceptional CO2/N2 selectivity of 71.3 while maintaining a CO2 permeance of 1,030 GPU without compromising the inherent gas separation performance of PDXL. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report to achieve the highest gas selectivity for CO2 gases as a UTFC membrane.

Anhydrous 1,3-dioxolane (DXL, 99.8 %, containing 75 ppm BHT as an inhibitor), calcium hydride (CaH2, reagent grade, 95 % (gas-volumetric)), 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA, contains ≤250 ppm monomethyl ether hydroquinone as an inhibitor, 97 %), anhydrous trifluoromethane sulfonic anhydride (Tf2O, ≥99 %), triethylamine (TEA, ≥99.5 %), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP, ≥98 %), hydroquinone (ReagentPlus®, 99 %), methacrylic anhydride (contains 2,000 ppm Topanol A as inhibitor, 94 %), 2-bromoisobutyryl bromide (BiBB, 98 %), 1,3,5-benzenetricarbonyl trichloride (TMC, 98 %), copper( Ι ) bromide (CuBr), and 2,2’-bipyridine (bpy) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. Aminopropyl terminated polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS-bis-NH2, 5.0 kDa) and poly[dimethylsiloxane-co-(3-aminopropyl)methylsiloxane] with 20–25 % pendant amino functionalities (poly(DMS-co-APMS), Mn = 20 kDa) were purchased from Gelest and used without further purification. Magnesium sulphate (MgSO4), n-hexane (AR grade, >99%), methanol (MeOH, AR grade, >99%), ethanol (EtOH, AR grade, >99%), chloroform (CHCl3, AR grade, >99%), and dichloromethane (DCM, AR grade, >99%) were purchased from Chem-Supply and MgSO4 was dried in the oven overnight before use. Anhydrous DCM was collected from a solvent purification system (Scitek SPBT-1 Bench Top Solvent Purifier) under ultrahigh purity (UHP) argon gas. Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3, Chem-Supply) and sodium chloride (NaCl, Supelco) were used after creating saturated solutions and hydrochloric acid (HCl, Ajax Finechem, 36%) was mixed with deionized water to obtain the desired molar solution. Deuterated chloroform (CDCl3, >99.8%) was purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories and used as received. Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, SolSep BV) substrates were pre-wetted in an ultrasonic bath with deionized water for 2h for use.

Anhydrous DXL was distilled over CaH2 in a N2 atmosphere for 2h at 80 °C before use. Collected DXL (10 g, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in 25 mL of anhydrous DCM in a 100 mL round bottom flask under N2 gas and subsequently, hydroquinone and 2.11 mL (17.4 mmol) of HEMA were added into the solution followed by 10 μL of anhydrous Tf2O. The solution was stirred overnight at room temperature, then terminated by adding 1 mL of TEA and stirred for an additional 30 min to neutralize the acidity. The solvent was evaporated under vacuum at 21 °C, and all of the unreacted chemicals were removed by high vacuum using liquid nitrogen. Finally, the precipitation was dried under high vacuum for 2 days at room temperature to obtain the desired product 1.

A round bottom flask equipped with a dropping funnel was oven dried and cooled under UHP argon prior to use. PDXLMA (8.0 mmol) was added to the flask followed by anhydrous TEA (3.9 ml, 28 mmol), DMAP (0.32 g, 2.64 mmol), and hydroquinone (0.10 g, 0.92 mmol). Methacrylic anhydride (3.7 mL, 26.4 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous DCM separately and placed in the dropping funnel. The methacrylic anhydride solution was added dropwise and the reaction mixture was left to stir at room temperature for 72h. The reaction mixture was diluted with DCM (100 mL) and washed with saturated NaHCO3 (3 x 100 mL), 0.5 M HCl (3 x 100 mL), and saturated NaCl (3 x 100 mL) before the combined organic phases were dried over MgSO4. The solvent was removed in vacuo (80 mbar) and the sample was kept under a high vacuum for 2 days in order to afford a pale-yellow product 2.

A round bottom flask equipped with a dropping funnel was oven dried and cooled under argon prior to use. Poly(DMS-co-APMS) (3, 2.0 g, 0.1 mmol, 4.5 mmol of aminopropyl groups; the aminopropyl groups were calculated based on 1H NMR result in CDCl3 (Fig. S1)) and anhydrous TEA (300 μL, 2.15 mmol) were added to the flask followed, by anhydrous THF (80 mL). The reaction mixture was cooled in an ice bath and BiBB (111 μL, 0.90 mmol) was added dropwise via a dropping funnel. Thereafter, the observed precipitation of triethylamine hydrobromide was removed by vacuum filtration followed by removal of THF in vacuo. The obtained product was redissolved in 100 mL DCM and washed with 0.1 M HCl (3 x 100 mL), saturated NaHCO3 (3 x 100 mL), and deionized water (3 x 100 mL). The combined organic phases were dried over MgSO4, filtered and reduced to dryness in vacuo to afford a pale-yellow product and concentrated by evaporating the solvent under vacuum. The obtained product 4 was redissolved in a mixture of CHCl3 and n-hexane (1.0 % w/v, CHCl3 (75 vol%) to n-hexane (25 vol%)) for further use.

The first gutter layer on PAN substrate was prepared similarly to our previous publication [6]. α,ω-PDMS-bis-NH2 (0.2 g, 0.04 mmol) was dissolved in n-hexane (10.0 mL, 2.0 % w/v), which was added to a solution of TMC (contained 7.0 mg of TMC, 0.0267 mmol) in n-hexane (0.35 mL). The two solutions were mixed for 400 s of pre-crosslinking time and 1 mL of the mixture was then spin-coated onto PAN substrate at 1,000 rpm for 10 s. The film was then dried overnight under vacuum to produce a PAN/PDMS membrane. The second initiator layer was produced by adding 1 mL of poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) solution (1.0 % w/v) to 1.42 mL of TMC solution (1.0 % w/v in n-hexane) and immediately coating this onto the prepared PDMS gutter layer (1,000 rpm, 10 s). The membrane was then dried overnight under vacuum to be ready for CAPATRP.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of UTFC membranes via CAPATRP
ce:section.ce:para: The underside of the PAN/PDMS/Poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) membrane was completely covered by a polyimide film, and placed in a N2 glass vial, to prevent solvent entering the pores by capillary action. Solution A was prepared consisting of CuBr (0.01 g, 14.0 mM), bpy (0.022 g, 28.0 mM) in the mixture of MeOH (3 mL) and milliQ water (1 mL). A second solution B was prepared containing PDXLDMA (1.31 g, 324 mM) in 1 mL of MeOH. Both solutions were degassed under ultrahigh purity argon gas for 30 min, then solution A was firstly added to the prepared vial followed by solution B. Highly crosslinked layer of PDXLDMA was thus produced from the initiation layer via CAPATRP at 70 °C for desired reaction times. The crosslinking reaction was terminated by quenching with the air and the membrane was rinsed with EtOH and water accordingly. The final UTFC membrane was vacuum-dried overnight at room temperature for further tests.

Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were acquired by the NMR Bruker Ascend™ 400 MHz spectrometer equipped with iProbe SmartProbe and all samples were prepared using deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) solvent. A Bruker Autoflex ΙΙΙ Mass Spectrometer was utilized to analyze Matrix assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-ToF MS) results, and trans-2-[3-(4-tert-butylphenyl)-2-methyl-2-propenylidene]malononitrile (DCTB, matrix, 10 mg/mL), potassium trifluoroacetate (KTFA, cationization agent, 1 mg/mL), and analytes (10 mg/mL) were dissolved in methanol (MeOH), subsequently they were mixed in a 10:1:1 ratio, respectively, for the measurement. Dataphysics OCA 20 was used to measure the water contact angle, and average angle values were derived after data were collected from at least three different spots on the membrane. Attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared (FTIR-ATR) spectra were obtained using a Bruker Nexus 470 Fourier-Transform Infrared Spectrometer from Bruker Corp with the setting of a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific Nexsa Surface Analysis System equipped with a hemispherical analyzer. The incident radiation was monochromatic Al K
α
X-rays (1486.6 eV) at 72 W (6 mA and 12 kV, 400 x 800
μ
m2 spot). Survey (wide) and high-resolution (narrow) scans were recorded at analyzer pass energies of 150 and 50 eV and step sizes of 1.0 eV and 0.1 eV, respectively. The base pressure in the analysis chamber was less than 5.0 × 10−9 mbar. A low-energy dual-beam (ion and electron) flood gun was used to compensate for surface charging. Data processing was carried out using Avantage software v5.9931 and the energy calibration was referenced to the main line of C1s at 284.8 eV. The background used for curve fitting was Smart. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were collected from an FEI Teneo VolumeScope at 10.00 kV and 50 pA as an accelerating voltage and a current, respectively. Membranes were first frozen in liquid nitrogen, and then they were swiftly snapped in half. All samples were coated with gold using a Safematic sputter coater (CCU-010) at a constant current of 30 mA, resulting in coatings that were 5 nm thick. With the use of an in-house constant pressure variable volume (CPVV)/ultrathin membrane (UTM) single gas, gas separation performance was evaluated and calculated in accordance with the previous report [6].

A UTFC membrane consisting of highly selective crosslinked PDXL, was prepared from a brominated initiation surface (4) grown by CAPATRP using PDXLMA macromonomer (Fig. 1 ). Initially, poly(1,3-dioxolane) dimethacrylate (PDXLDMA) macromonomer was prepared via a two-step chemical synthesis, Fig. 2 a. Poly(1,3-dioxolane) methacrylate (PDXLMA) was firstly synthesized through cationic ring-opening polymerization (CROP) of 1,3-dioxolane (DXL) to produce telechelic -
α
-hydroxyl-
ω
-methacrylyl poly(1,3-dioxolane) (PDXLMA). The
α
-hydroxyl group of the resulting PDXLMA (1) was then functionalized with methacrylic anhydride to produce the crosslinking macromonomer PDXLDMA (2). The synthesis of precursor PDXLMA (1) and difunctional macromonomer PDXLDMA (2) were confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 2b). The peaks at
δ
6.05 ppm, 5.05 ppm, and 1.88 ppm correspond to methacrylate groups a, b, and g, respectively [19]. 1H NMR peaks at
δ
4.68 ppm and 3.65 ppm were observed due to methylene (–CH2–) and ethylene (–CH2–CH2-), moieties of DXL repeat unit, respectively consistent with previous literature [19,29]. Further evidence of PDXLDMA (2) formation was afforded by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-MoF MS). Verification of the polymer backbone was evidenced by a difference in m/z of 74.08, equivalent to the polymer repeat unit of DXL, demonstrating successful CROP. Furthermore, a shift in m/z by 68.1 from PDXLMA (1) to PDXLDMA (2) demonstrated successful incorporation of a second methacrylate group at the
α
-position Fig. 3 b. The molecular weight of 539.6 amu for PDXLMA (n = 5, M+ + K+) and 607.7 amu for PDXLDMA (n = 5, M+ + K+) verified successful synthesis of both polymers (Fig. 3a). The molecular weight, number-average molar mass (M
n ), weight-average molar mass (M
w ), and polydispersity (Đ) were calculated by equations (Eq. S1-3) [30]. The M
n and M
w for PDXLMA (1) were 652.3 g/mol and 785.8 g/mol, respectively with a polydispersity of 1.20. PDXLDMA (2) displayed, a M
n and M
w of 712.9 g/mol and 808.5 g/mol, respectively, with a narrow polydispersity of 1.13, indicating a well-controlled synthesis of macrocrosslinker PDXLDMA (2).

To overcome the poor adhesion between a hydrophobic PDMS gutter layer and the hydrophilic polar PDXLDMA layer, a modified continuous assembly of polymers (CAP) technique was adopted to chemically bind the two in fabricating a well-controlled and uniform UTFC membrane. CAP technology provides strong covalent bonds between polymer layers, in addition to defect-free surfaces and greater mechanical stability [2]. Our previous CAPATRP approach used a brominated initiation layer precursor which fully functionalized the terminal amine groups of
α , ω
-PDMS-bis-NH2 making them unavailable to participate in crosslinking with the underneath PDMS layer. This may lead to possible delamination due to the incompatibility of the initiaion and gutter layers [26,31]. Therefore, in this study, the pendent amine groups of brush poly(DMS-co-APMS) (3) was partially modified with bromoisobutyryl bromide to form poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4), containing residual amine functional groups for crosslinking and bromine groups for initiating the CAPATRP reaction (Fig. 4 a). 1H NMR was used to confirm the successful formation of poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4). The peaks at
δ
1.98 ppm and 1.92 ppm PDMS were consistent with the brominated methyl groups (f, –C(CH3)2-Br) of the PDMS backbone, with peaks appearing between 1.98 ppm and 1.92 ppm. Additionally, the peak e at
δ
3.25 ppm appeared after modification which is due to the methylene group (e, –CH2-CH2-NH) of the brominated chain. Partial functionalization of the amine groups is confirmed by the presence of the initial methylene peak d at
δ
2.6 ppm in the final product [26].

To ensure a homogenous CAP polymerization, ATRP was utilized for a well-controlled crosslinked polymer network growing from the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) initiation layer (Fig. 1a). The CAPATRP reaction was utilized to grow PDXLDMA (2) from the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) initiation layer, by injecting the degassed CuBr/2,2’-bipyridyl complex and PDXLDMA solutions under N2. Fig. 1b illustrates the CAPATRP reaction of the macrocrosslinker, PDXLDMA (2). The edge of the initiation layer was covered with polyimide film to prevent capillary action into the pores of the support layer and also had the benefit of showing two distinct layers after the CAPATRP reaction, the initiation layer and the PDXLDMA layer. As shown in Fig. 1b, the crosslinked PDXLDMA was shown as a glossy layer on top of the UTFC membrane without any visible defects. The water contact angles of the ultrathin polymer layers were measured to qualitatively determine the changes in surface chemistry. Fig. 5 a shows the water contact angle images of the different polymer coatings, with the values shown in Fig. 5b. The water contact angles for the PDMS gutter layer and the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) initiation layer were 115.1 ± 0.78° and 106.1 ± 4.67°, respectively. This is consistent with a slight increase in the hydrophilicity from the hydrophobic PDMS gutter layer, due to the functionalization with amino alkyl groups and bromo-functional initiator moiety [32]. When the hydrophilic PDXLDMA polymer was grown on the initiation layer using CAPATRP, a reduction in the contact angle to 87.9 ± 4.64° was observed, confirming successful surface polymerization. Attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) also verified the successful growth of PDXLDMA by CAPATRP) (Fig. 6 ). No significant differences were observed between the gutter and initiation layers due to the bulk of the materials consisting of PDMS (Fig. 3b). However, analysis of the crosslinked PDXLDMA dense CAPATRP film showed a reduction in peak at 1658.3 cm−1 associated with the acrylate groups (CC) [33]. In addition, a stronger signal from the methyl group (C-CH3) stretching at 2942.0 cm−1 and methylene (C-H) stretching at 2884.5 cm−1 after the CAPATRP, is consistent with an increase in the methyl groups due to the crosslinking on the membrane surface [34,35]. Furthermore, the CAPATRP layer and its dense film showed a peak corresponding to the stretching signal of ester groups (C-O) at 1167.4 cm−1, which corresponds to the main structure of PDXLDMA [35–37]. The elemental analysis of each layer was demonstrated using x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which was used to establish that the layers were well-deposited and to characterize their chemical bonds after crosslinking reactions. The peak-fitting result for the Si2p core level on the PDMS layer shows the typical two signals of siloxane groups that correspond to the Si2p3/2 and Si2p1/2 electron spin states at 101.98 eV and 102.61 eV, respectively (Fig. 7 a) [38,39]. After coating the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) layer on top of the PDMS layer, the high-resolution C1s spectra showed the C-N peak at 285.34 eV and the CO peak at 288.65 eV, and the peaks at 400.01 eV and 401.48 eV, which correspond to the chemical bonds N-CO and C-N, respectively, also observed in the peak-fitting findings of N1s (Fig. 7b and c) [40–42]. This indicates that the crosslinking reaction and partial modification of the amine to bromine moieties were successful, and the bromine peak, Br3d, was clearly observed at 68.66 eV on the initiation layer as shown in Fig. 7d. The four distinct chemical bonds of the crosslinked PDXLDMA were clearly detected in the C1s peak-fitting results (Fig. 7e). Due to the repeat units in highly crosslinked PDXLDMA, the majority of the peaks detected at 285.42 eV and 287.10 eV correspond to C-C and C-O, respectively [43]. Furthermore, the high-resolution O1s spectra is consistent with the crosslinked PDXLDMA structure as well as the peak-fitting C1s data as shown in Fig. S2h [42]. When the PDXLDMA was crosslinked via CAPATRP, the N1s peak and Si2p peaks disappeared, indicating full coverage of the ultrathin composite membrane (Fig. S2d). Similarly, noise only without any peaks from the high-resolution N1s data demonstrated the crosslinked PDXLDMA completely covered the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) initiation layer, resulting in the disappearance of the N1s peaks (Fig. 7f). Combined, these findings confirm the successful formation of the crosslinked CAPATRP layer with PDXLDMA in creating a UTFC membrane that is entirely coated and free of defects.

The CAPATRP reaction time was used to control the thickness of the top selective layers grown from the poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) (4) initiation layer (Fig. S3). It was observed that a reaction time of 30 min was insufficient to produce defect-free films. The UTFC membrane thicknesses and morphology of the top layers that were prepared at 2, 3, and 4 h reaction time, were determined using scanning electron microscope (SEM) as shown in Fig. 8 a. The thickness of the polymer layer increased with increasing CAPATRP reaction time. The thickness of the membrane was 145.3 ± 19.2 nm at 2h and increased to 195.9 ± 19.7 nm at 3h, and 247.7 ± 7.3 nm at 4h reaction time (Fig. 8b). It is noteworthy to observe that nonuniform bumps formed on the surface when the reaction time reached 4h. This indicates that 2–3 h reaction time are optimal for producing a homogeneous uniform polymer film. Y. Li et al. observed that when macrocrosslinker reached high conversion between 97 and 99.9 % during ATRP, it showed significant changes in Mw and high polydispersity due to macrogelations. Therefore, we hypothesize that after 3h reaction time, the macrocrosslinker in the CAPATRP system either macrogelates or leads to increased side reactions of non-controlled CAPATRP [44]. The CO2 gas permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity for UTFC membranes at various reaction times is shown in Fig. 8c as a means of examining the impact of the CAP reaction time on gas separation performance. The theoretical CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity of membranes with different thicknesses, were calculated according to the resistance-in-series model ( Eqs. S4-8) [14,45,46]. The ideal CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity at CAPATRP 4h were predicted to be 800 GPU and 69.4, respectively, however the experimental performance showed a CO2 permeance of 204 GPU and a CO2/N2 selectivity of 57.5. This is because the thickness of the resistance-in-series model was based on the SEM cross-sectional image, but the presence of thicker regions due to nonuniform bumps could lead to an increase in the actual average thickness, potentially causing the decrease in gas permeance and selectivity. On the other hand, the ideal CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity under CAPATRP2h are 1,355 GPU and 69 of CO2/N2, respectively (Table 1 ). The measured CO2 permeance was 1,013 GPU at CAPATRP 2h which is almost as high as the theoretical value of PDXL's inherent CO2 permeability. In other words, ATRP system enables the control of the polymer growth from the initiation surface without pore blocking. Importantly, the CO2/N2 selectivity significantly increased from 10.7 to 71.3, indicating pinhole-free and complete coverage with crosslinked PDXL. Even a small fraction of the defects would cause a significant reduction in gas selectivity [47]. However, this study maintains the optimum gas separation property of the PDXL based polymer after the UTFC membrane fabrication by using a newly developed and well-controlled CAPATRP technique. The CAPATRP 2h-UTFC membrane, which was prepared under optimal conditions, was tested to determine its physical and thermal stabilities under a variety of conditions, including temperature and pressure (Fig. 9 a and b). Gas membrane performances were measured at temperatures between 30 °C and 55 °C, and feed pressures between 0.5 bar and 4.0 bar, representing conditions of gas separation experienced in CO2 post-combustion [48]. Fig. 9a shows the gas separation performance of the CAPATRP 2h-UTFC membrane under various temperatures. It was observed that the CO2 permeance increased from 1,007 GPU at 30 °C to 1,122 GPU at 55 °C. In contrast, CO2/N2 selectivity decreased from 72.7 at 30 °C to 62.6 at 55 °C. The ethoxy units of amorphous PDXL segments have a strong affinity to CO2 gas resulting in high CO2 solubility. With increasing temperatures, the CO2 diffusivity increases, while the CO2 solubility decreases. This results in the permeance of both CO2 and N2 increasing, which reduces CO2/N2 selectivity [19,49]. Nonetheless, the trend for CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity was relatively steady. Remarkably, the CAPATRP 2h-UTFC membrane performed consistently under a range of feed pressures for both CO2 permeance and CO2/N2 selectivity (Fig. 9b). This may be because of the high mechanical and chemical strength of the membrane afforded by the highly crosslinked covalently bonded layers [26,31]. To demonstrate its outstanding performance in gas separation, the CAPATRP-UTFC membranes with different reaction times were evaluated in comparison to related published TFC membranes. Results from published TFC membranes of CO2 permeance calculated from their gas flux were chosen to assess each material's performance. This distinction gives a true evaluation of the throughput a membrane can achieve, which incorporates membrane thickness, and is becoming recognized more important than gas permeability [50,51]. Additionally, performances below either CO2 permeances of 10 GPU or CO2/N2 selectivities of 10 were not considered due to their limitation in practical applications. Data points were collected from various material types and different classes of materials represented by different icons. (Fig. 10 ). The revised Robeson's upper bounds were plotted with the membrane thicknesses of 200 nm, 400 nm, and 1
μ
m in order to illustrate the trade-off slope between gas permeance and selectivity, and assess its remarkable gas separation performance [52,53]. It is evident that the majority of existing membranes fall below the 200 nm line, which represents the cutting edge of the current best-performing membranes. As a result, CAPATRP-UTFC membranes prepared with 2h and 3h reaction times, having thicknesses of 145.3
±
19.2 nm and 195.9
±
19.7 nm, exceed the revised Robeson's upper bound, showing their extraordinary gas separation performance with great excitement.

An adapted CAP technology using ATRP was successfully utilized to produce novel hydrophilic PDXL-UTFC membranes that are covalently bonded to a non-compatible hydrophobic permeable gutter layer. Furthermore, the crosslinking chemistry was controlled to produce desirable ultrathin homogeneous selective layers without defects or pinholes. A partially modified poly(DMS-co-APMS-co-BIBAPMS) gutter layer provided an initiation surface for successfully controlled CAPATRP. This approach addressed the material incompatibility between the hydrophobic gutter and hydrophilic selective layer by covalently bonding the PDXLDMA selective layer to the initiation layer. Crosslinking the CAP initiator to the PDMS gutter layer avoided any potential for delamination. Remarkably, the CAPATRP-2h UTFC membrane exhibits excellent CO2/N2 selectivity of 71.3, as a result of its highly polar ethoxy groups and CO2 permeance of 1,013 GPU. To the best of our knowledge, the gas selectivity is the highest performance achieved compared to other TFC membranes, under the polymeric gas solution-diffusion mechanism reported in the literature. The CAPATRP-UTFC membranes prepared with 2h and 3h reaction times surpassed the revised Robeson's upper bound with an assumed membrane thickness of 200 nm. The results reported here represent a significant milestone in the development of advanced polymer-based composite membranes and associated coating technologies. The modified CAPATRP is anticipated to be scalable within a continuous manufacturing process that operates in a closed environment. Furthermore, exploring alternative controlled polymerization methods is a potential avenue for reducing the reaction time to acquire desired membrane thicknesses, which would increase throughput.
